document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Afrotropical genus Scolopsomorpha Melichar (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Tropiduchidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Afrotropical genus Scolopsomorpha Melichar (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Tropiduchidae)

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Dedicated to its collector, Mr. Domir DeBakker ( MRAC ).

Material examined. Holotype 3 : [Coll. I.R.Sc.N.B., Congo ( RDC ), Mayombe, Bas-Congo, Luki Biosphere Reserve,

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6 A–L. A–D,
Scolopsomorpha africana .
A, habitus, dorsal view. B, habitus, lateral view. C, head, ventral view. D, right hind wing. E–H,
S. boulardi
. E, habitus, lateral view. F, head, ventral view. G, right hind wing. H, habitus, dorsal view. I–L,
S. debakkeri
. I, habitus, dorsal view. J, habitus, lateral view. K, head, ventral view. L, right hind wing.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Other material examined: 1 Ƥ: [ Congo belge , Bambesa,
26 -I- 1939
, J. Vrydagh] [R. Mus. Hist. Nat. Belg. I. G. 12.291 ] ( RBINS ) coordinates of Bambesa:
3 ° 28 'N
25 ° 43 'E
.
Note: this female is not included in the paratype series because no male has been collected together which would confirm the identity of the species.
Description. LT: 3 (n = 3 ): 9.6 mm ( 9.5–9.7 ); Ƥ (n = 3 ): 10.5 mm (10.0– 11.1 ). L [anterior margin of eye – apex of tegmina]: 3 (n = 3 ): 7.2 mm ; Ƥ (n = 3 ): 8 mm ( 7.9–8.2 ).

Tegmina : tubercles pale yellow-brown to pale yellow-red; ground colour black brown on basal ¼, on large lateral zone at middle and on apical 1 / 5 ; rest red-brown with pale patch along lateral margin at basal 1 / 3 ; apical shiny black spot elevated; all parts more or less suffused with red, especially veins; apex of clavus black-brown (
Figs.
6 I
–J
); underside largely red; ratio LTg/BTg = [ 3 ] 3.33 ; [Ƥ] = 2.94 .

Hind wings
: black-brown with veins slightly suffused with red (
Fig. 6 L
).
Abdomen : pale yellow ventrally, dark brown dorsally.

Biology. Six specimens have been caught by canopy fogging in Bas-Congo, which may suggest that the species lives in the tree tops. Another specimen has been collected in NE Congo and this suggests that the species has a large distribution.
